subject: apgov
title: McCulloch v. Maryland
quickTake: Congress can create the Bank of the United States, and Maryland cannot tax it.
corePrompt: Does Congress have the power to create a national bank, and can a state tax it?
answerText: Congress has implied powers under the Necessary and Proper Clause to create a national bank, and state taxes that interfere with valid federal action are unconstitutional under the Supremacy Clause.
facts: Congress chartered the Second Bank of the United States.
Maryland passed a tax targeting the bank.
James McCulloch, a bank cashier, refused to pay the tax and was sued by Maryland.
reasoning: The Constitution grants Congress enumerated powers plus implied powers needed to carry them out.
The Necessary and Proper Clause supports means that are useful and appropriate for executing enumerated powers.
States cannot use taxation to control or destroy federal institutions because federal law is supreme.
precedent: Strengthened the idea of implied powers.
Reinforced federal supremacy when state action conflicts with valid federal action.

terms.definition: Powers not explicitly listed but reasonably derived from enumerated powers.
Allows Congress to make laws needed to carry out its listed powers.
Federal law is the supreme law of the land when validly enacted.

whyExam: Common example of implied powers and federal supremacy.
Often used to explain how the national government can expand authority through interpretation.
whyReal: Supports a strong national government in disputes with states.
Used as a foundation for later federal power cases.
leadsTo: Gibbons v. Ogden (1824) for national power in the economy
connectsBack: Constitutional Convention debates over a stronger national government

subject: apgov
title: Gibbons v. Ogden
quickTake: Only Congress can regulate interstate commerce, including navigation.
corePrompt: Can New York grant a monopoly that blocks a federally licensed operator from running steamboats between states?
answerText: The Commerce Clause gives Congress power over interstate commerce, and federal licensing overrides conflicting state laws.
facts: New York granted an exclusive steamboat operating right to Ogden.
Gibbons operated competing steamboats using a federal coastal license.
Ogden sued to stop Gibbons under the New York monopoly.
reasoning: Commerce includes navigation when it crosses state lines.
When Congress acts within its commerce power, conflicting state restrictions are invalid.
The decision favors a single national market over state barriers.
precedent: Expanded the scope of the Commerce Clause.
Limited state-created economic barriers that conflict with federal authority.

terms.definition: Gives Congress power to regulate commerce among the states.
Economic activity that crosses state lines or affects trade between states.

whyExam: Key case for understanding the Commerce Clause and federal supremacy.
Often paired with McCulloch to show early strengthening of national power.
whyReal: Helped create consistent rules for trade across states.
Cited in later debates about federal regulation of the economy.
leadsTo: Later Commerce Clause cases that test the limits of federal regulation
connectsBack: McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) for national supremacy over conflicting state action
